update.description:
This version of the library should allow to publish/subscribe messages between nodes and make synchronous and asynchronous service call requests. The messages are typed and if the nodes are within the same process, no serialization should be done.

Requires: zeromq, czmq, robot_msgs, protobuf, and uuid-dev. It also requires c++11 (as probably most of the ignition projects).

Take a look at src/Node_TEST to see how to use the library while I'm writing the tutorials.

From a design point of view, these are the building blocks I've used to create a node in each process.

```
 _______   _______
|       | |       |
| Node 1| | Node 2|
|_______| |_______|
|                 |
|   Node Shared   |
|_________________|
|                 |
|     Discovery   |
|_________________|
     (Process1)
```

This is the [drone.io
job status](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_transport).

[![Build Status](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_transport/status.png)](https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_transport/latest)
update.title: Initial complete version

content.raw:
That was excellent intuition, recompiling protobuf with `--c++11` fixed the build, though it gave an ominous warning:
~~~
Warning: ignition-transport dependency boost was built with a different C++ standard
library (libstdc++ from clang). This could cause problems at runtime.
~~~
boost is a transitive dependency from robot_msgs. I think it would be best to keep robot_msgs from depending on boost ([issue here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/robot_msgs/issue/3/remove-boost-dependency))
content.html:
That was excellent intuition, recompiling protobuf with --c++11 fixed the build, though it gave an ominous warning:

Warning: ignition-transport dependency boost was built with a different C++ standard
library (libstdc++ from clang). This could cause problems at runtime.

boost is a transitive dependency from robot_msgs. I think it would be best to keep robot_msgs from depending on boost (issue here)

~~~

content.raw:
In debian/ubuntu, they are shipping this header together with zeromq package. For homebrew, I've [imported it](https://github.com/j-rivero/homebrew-simulation/blob/master/cppzmq.rb) from https://github.com/bertjwregeer/homebrew-compat/

**update:** it is a good idea to include it in the SearchForStuff. I've created the branch ```transport_0.3.0_jrivero``` and commited af1e953 to make this possible. Tested on Linux.
content.html:
In debian/ubuntu, they are shipping this header together with zeromq package. For homebrew, I've imported it from https://github.com/bertjwregeer/homebrew-compat/

update: it is a good idea to include it in the SearchForStuff. I've created the branch transport_0.3.0_jrivero and commited af1e953 to make this possible. Tested on Linux.

content.raw: Perhaps we should add that to the readme? `cppzmq` is not in the list of required packages
content.html: Perhaps we should add that to the readme? cppzmq is not in the list of required packages

content.raw: Yes, if you want to compile from sources you need [zeromq](https://github.com/zeromq/zeromq4-x), [czmq V2.2](https://github.com/zeromq/czmq), and [cppzmq](https://github.com/zeromq/cppzmq)
content.html: Yes, if you want to compile from sources you need zeromq, czmq V2.2, and cppzmq

content.raw: On paper, std::unordered_map should be faster for our use case because we don't need sorted keys and we don't iterate over all the elements. Our use case is ideal for std::unordered_map. Unordered_map uses a hash instead of a tree and I read that the hash function doesn't work really well with strings as keys. So, we should benchmark it before changing it. It's an interesting topic!
content.html: On paper, std::unordered_map should be faster for our use case because we don't need sorted keys and we don't iterate over all the elements. Our use case is ideal for std::unordered_map. Unordered_map uses a hash instead of a tree and I read that the hash function doesn't work really well with strings as keys. So, we should benchmark it before changing it. It's an interesting topic!

content.html: Using a boolean as return value in TopicStorage and HandlerStorage classes. (9183231)

content.raw: This type is included in the header of the discovery message and I want to use just a byte. unsigned int uses at least two bytes.
content.html: This type is included in the header of the discovery message and I want to use just a byte. unsigned int uses at least two bytes.

update.description:
This version of the library should allow to publish/subscribe messages between nodes and make synchronous and asynchronous service call requests. The messages are typed and if the nodes are within the same process, no serialization should be done.

Requires: zeromq, czmq, robot_msgs, protobuf, and uuid-dev. It also requires c++11 (as probably most of the ignition projects).

Take a look at src/Node_TEST to see how to use the library while I'm writing the tutorials.

From a design point of view, these are the building blocks I've used to create a node in each process.

```
 _______   _______
|       | |       |
| Node 1| | Node 2|
|_______| |_______|
|                 |
|   Node Shared   |
|_________________|
|                 |
|     Discovery   |
|_________________|
```
update.title: Initial complete version
